subject: Submitting a link to the JUnit page
msgSnippet: I know the JUnit homepage lists article and links of interest to users of JUnit, and I was wondering if anyone on the list knew whom I would submit a potential
messageBody:
I know the JUnit homepage lists article and links of interest to users of
JUnit, and I was wondering if anyone on the list knew whom I would submit a
potential link to.

I recently co-authored a book (with Rick Hightower) covering Automated
Testing and continuous integration using JUnit and several of the extensions
that have also been listed on the web-page (JUnitPerf, HttpUnit, and
Cactus). It also covers Ant and JMeter (a couple of essential Jakarta
projects). The book includes a case study in applying each framework to an
online pet store, and would serve as an excellent resource for anyone
wishing to explore JUnit as well as several of it OS extensions.

The homepage for the book, including on-line source code is at:

http://www.rickhightower.com/JavaXPToolkit/

We're working on getting a couple of sample chapters up for your perusal.
The book can be purchased directly from John Wiley at:

http://www.wiley.com/Corporate/Website/Objects/Products/0,9049,1847817,00.ht
ml

or Amazon.com at:

http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/047120708X/qid=1008780346/sr=8-1/ref=
sr_8_3_1/103-8597614-7170265

Sorry for this sounding like a plug--I mean it is, but I think the book
would be of legitimate interest to users of JUnit, both the readers of the
mailing list and the viewers of the web-page. Part of our goal in writing it
was to generate publicity for the tools that have helped us so much.

Cheers,

Nick
